Facebook is mulling a plan to sell its upcoming smart speakers internationally before launching them in the U.S., as American users and politicians have increased their focus on Facebook and user privacy, according to two people who have had discussions with the company about the devices.

The devices will also come equipped with a smart voice assistant that's tied to Facebook's artificial intelligence program, M.

Among other uses, M previously powered a personal assistant chatbot on Messenger, but Facebook shut that incarnation down in January.
The speakers, one of which will come with a camera and a touch screen, will connect directly to Facebook Messenger to make chatting with friends and family through the service much easier.
After news that political research firm Cambridge Analytica was able to gain access to unauthorized user data through the guise of a personality quiz, Facebook found itself in hot water.
CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified in Congress over data privacy issues in April, and the company has made several moves to allow users to control which companies have access to their data.
The two devices, which Facebook had intended on announcing at its F8 Developer Conference on Tuesday, are the company's answer to Amazon's Echo and Alphabet's Google Home products.
CLOSE Speaking in San Jose, California at Facebook's F8 gathering of tech folks, startups and others, Zuckerberg said that 2018 has been an "intense year" just four months in.
On Tuesday at F8, Facebook announced M Translations, a Messenger and Marketplace feature that translates foreign languages into a Messenger user's default language.
Many marketers said Facebook's foray seemed a little too late considering that Amazon and Google's smart speakers already have a robust ecosystem of apps.

The company has played around with calling the assistant by some name that begins with the letter "M," multiple sources said.
An international rollout could also help Facebook make a bigger splash in markets where competitors are weaker.
